newsitem.title: CANADA: NatWest restarts Potash with "buy" rating.
newsitem.headline: NatWest restarts Potash with "buy" rating.

text.p: NatWest Securities Corp reinstated coverage of Canadian fertilizer company Potash Corp of Saskatchewan with a "buy" rating, NatWest analyst David Nelson said on Monday.

NatWest had been restricted from commenting on Saskatoon, Saskatchewan-based Potash Corp while the brokerage acted as adviser to the company for its acquisition of nitrogen fertilizer producer Arcadian Corp.

Nelson told a conference call that his firm came back with its long-standing recommendation because of Potash's dominance in each of the businesses it operates, a strong cash flow and earnings outlook and industry consolidation among companies producing each of the three nutrients.

He said he assumed Potash would make about US$100 million per year in debt repayments, which would leave about US$322 million or US$6 per share of free cash flow to reinvest at 15 percent on a pre-tax basis.
"When you make that assumption and apply conservative market assumptions, we get earnings growth for this company in excess of 20 percent per year," Nelson said.

"That's clearly less -- and we're trying to be conservative -- than they've shown over the last five years," he said. However, Nelson said the forecast was favorable for investors because Potash was trading at a 50 percent discount to NatWest's forecast 1998 earnings of US$8 per share.
Nelson predicted a favorable outcome in Potash Corp's stalled attempt to acquire German potash producer Kali & Salz SDGF.F from majority owner BASF AG.
The German Cartel Office barred the sale in late February, a move that Potash and BASF appealed.

He said Germany's commerce department, which is required to respond to the appeal within four months, should find that combining Kali & Salz with Potash Corp will strengthen the company and boost employment levels in the country.
"We think the odds on that going through around mid-year are pretty good," Nelson said.
